key_points: Oil prices rose on Monday due to a cyberattack on the Colonial Pipeline in the US.
The attack caused fears of prolonged outages, boosting oil prices despite COVID-19 spread in Asia.
Colonial Pipeline is a key part of the US's oil infrastructure, transporting over 2.5 million bpd of refined products.
Prices of gasoline and diesel increased, with expectations of short supply as long as the pipeline is offline.
Localized impacts are expected, with increased prices at the pump in northeastern and southeastern states.
European refiners may increase exports to the US, though immediate impact may be limited.
The closure could lead to US crude exports being kept domestically to replenish inventories.
The bullish developments in the US are overshadowing the worrying COVID-19 trend in Asia.
If the pipeline is quickly restored, the market might see a price correction influenced by the pandemic's spread in Asia.
The full effect of the pipeline outage on inventories will be visible in official data next week, affecting future oil price directions.
spokespersons: Louise Dickson (Oil Markets Analyst, Rystad Energy)
